item.title: GameCube Classic Fire Emblem: Path of Radiance Joins Switch Online
item.content:encoded:
Another GameCube game has been added to the Nintendo Switch Online library, and this time, it's the turn of classic turn-based strategy epic Fire Emblem: Path of Radiance.

Just like every other GameCube game on the service, Fire Emblem: Path of Radiance is only available if you're a Switch 2 owner with the Expansion Pack addon for your Switch Online membership, but if you do fulfil those criteria, you can check it out right now.

Path of Radiance was released all the way back in 2005 (and, incidentally, was my introduction to the Fire Emblem series, as I'm sure it was for many). The game follows Ike, a mercenary who gets caught up in a conflict between nations and who must help a princess reclaim her throne.

Much like its predecessors (and, indeed, its successors), Fire Emblem: Path of Radiance is a turn-based strategy RPG in which you'll be issuing commands to your characters and trying to keep them alive throughout various combat scenarios.

The game features permadeath, so if any of your troops fall during a battle, they're gone for good. Even plot-critical characters can fall in this way, although they'll be gravely wounded rather than dead, so you'll still see them during cutscenes.

Path of Radiance is the first Fire Emblem game to feature fully-rendered 3D graphics, as well as voice acting and FMV cutscenes, but it's not the first title to come to the West; that honor goes to 2003's eponymous Fire Emblem (which is also on Switch Online!).

You can check out a trailer for Fire Emblem: Path of Radiance's Switch Online release right here. The trailer's in Japanese, but the game is available across the world, so you won't exclusively be playing the Japanese version.

Fire Emblem: Path of Radiance is available right now to Nintendo Switch Online subscribers with a Switch 2 and the Expansion Pack addon. Stay tuned for more.

item.title: Divinity Concept Art Work Won't Include Gen AI, but Other Aspects Might
item.content:encoded:
Larian Studios' Swen Vincke has walked back the company's stance on using generative AI during concept art development, but that doesn't mean the tech won't be used elsewhere in the upcoming Divinity's development.

As part of an AMA on Reddit (as spotted by Stephen Totilo on Bluesky), Vincke responded to a user's questions about his feelings on generative AI, saying that Larian had "decided to refrain from using gen AI tools during concept art development" in order to prevent "discussion about the origin of the art".

However, Vincke followed that comment up by saying that he still thinks generative AI can "improve the speed" with which Larian experiments and "refine[s] ideas", leading to a "more focused development cycle, less waste, and ultimately, a higher-quality game".

Vincke says Larian won't use what he calls "creative assets" without "being 100% sure about the origins of the training data and the consent of those who created the data". He says if generative AI is used to create assets, it will be "trained on data [Larian owns]".

There is, however, a question mark (as pointed out by one Bluesky user) around whether such a thing is possible; it's likely that any gen AI model used by Larian will be based on pre-existing models, which have often been trained on data of questionable origin.

The generative AI debate continues to rage in the gaming sphere. Some companies, like Xbox and EA, have wholeheartedly embraced it, while others, including the likes of Manor Lords publisher Hooded Horse, have denounced the tech in no uncertain terms.

Generative AI isn't going anywhere anytime soon, though, it seems; our very own Don's research has revealed that almost 20% of Steam's top sellers in 2025 used generative AI in some way, shape, or form.

In any case, it's unlikely that Divinity will be free from generative AI when it launches, although that day may be very far away indeed. Stay tuned for more.
